columns.text:
In this problem, we will determine how much Bilbo Baggins needs to save monthly from year 11 to 30 to meet his objectives if he can save $2,350 per month for the next ten years and earn 10% EAR before retirement and 7% after. The following are the three objectives:

- Objective 1: Retirement income after 30 years of $17,500 per month for the next 25 years
- Objective 2: Purchase a cavin in ten years at an estimated cost of $345,000
- Objective 3: After 25 years with monthly retirement income passes, leave an inheritance worth $2,000,000 to a relative

First, let's determine the annual percentage rate Baggins can earn before and after retirement.

This calculation will calculate the annual percentage rate or APR from EAR, the effective annual rate, and the provided period.

The APR refers to the annual rate a lender can quote its customer as prescribed by laws. We will consider the following formula to calculate the APR using the effective annual rate:


$$ \begin{aligned}
APR &=m\times\left(\left(1+EAR\right)^{\dfrac{1}{m}}-1\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$APR$, which means the annual percentage rate\
$m$. which indicates the period\
$EAR$, which represents the effective annual rate

We will consider the following details in calculating the APR before and after Baggin's retirement:

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| EAR pre-retirement  | 10% |
| EAR post-retirement | 7%  |
| Period              | 12  |

Note that EAR or the effective annual rate is based on a year; hence the period is twelve, representing the number of months in a year.

Using the APR formula, let's now calculate Baggin's APR pre-retirement.

$$ \begin{aligned}
APR &=12\times\left(\left(1+0.10\right)^{\dfrac{1}{12}}-1\right)
\\[15pt]
&=12\times0.00797414
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{9.57\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, Baggin's APR before he retires is 9.57%.

Let's calculate the APR post-retirement of Baggin.

$$ \begin{aligned}
APR &=12\times\left(\left(1+0.07\right)^{\dfrac{1}{12}}-1\right)
\\[15pt]
&=12\times0.005654145
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{6.78\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the APR after he retires is 6.78%.

Next, based on the pre-retirement and the post-retirement annual percentage rate, let's calculate the total amount required per Baggin's objective.

Let's start by calculating the total post-retirement required amount. The post-retirement goals are Baggin's first and the third objective.

Considering the nominal rate post-retirement, calculate the present value annuity of the first objective.

- Objective 1: Retirement income after 30 years of $17,500 per month for the next 25 years

In calculating the present value of objective one, we will consider the following details from the objective.

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| Constant payment  | $17,500 |
| Rate | 6.78%  |
| Period              | 25 (years) |

Next, since the periodic payment is monthly, we will multiply 25 years by the number of months in a year.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &= 12\times25
\\[5pt]
&= 300
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the period we will consider is on a monthly basis of 300.

The present value of an annuity calculates the current value of a series of periodic payments in the future multiplied by the rate and period factor. Hence, we will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
PVA &=C\times\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{\left(1+r\right)^t}}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PVA$, which means the present value of an annuity\
$C$, which represent the cash amount or the constant payment\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Next, since objective two is set to achieve ten years before he retires, let's first calculate the present value of objective three using the post-retirement nominal rate.

- Objective 3: After 25 years with monthly retirement income passes, leave an inheritance worth $2,000,000 to a relative

To calculate the present value of the third objective of Baggin, we will consider the following details:

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| Future value  | $2,000,000 |
| Rate | 6.78%  |
| Period              | 25 (years) |

Note that the rate is the calculated APR post-retirement.

To determine the present value of an inheritance, a future amount, we divide the future value over the rate and the period. The formula to calculate the present value is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
PV &=\dfrac{{FV}}{\left(1 + r\right)^{t}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$FV$, which indicate the future value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which show the discount rate

Next, we will convert the period in monthly value from years.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &= 12\times25
\\[5pt]
&= 300
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the period we will consider is 300.

Let's now identify the total amount required after retirement.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Post-Retirement Total Amount Required} &= \$2,525,955.68+\$368,954.33
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$2,894,910.01}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our calculation, the total amount required post-retirement to meet Baggin's objective is $2,894,910.01.

Next, determine the pre-retirement amount required to meet Baggin's objective. The pre-retirement objective is the second objective.

- Objective 2: Purchase a cavin in ten years at an estimated cost of $345,000

Since the second objective is set ten years from now, we will calculate the future value annuity of the fixed amount he can save for ten years which is $2,350 monthly.

In calculating the future value, we will consider the following details from the problem:

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| Constant payment  | $2,350 |
| Rate | 9.57%  |
| Period              | 10 (years) |
| Cost of the cabin  | $345,000 |

Note that the nominal rate we will use in this computation is the pre-retirement rate since objective two is before Baggin's retirement.

The future value of an annuity refers to the value of a periodic, constant cash flow at a future date. It is calculated based on the interest rate and the period. The formula to determine the future value is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
FVA &=C\times\dfrac{\left(1+r\right)^t-1}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PFA$, which means the future value of an annuity\
$C$, which represent the cash amount or the constant payment\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

First, since the annuity is monthly, convert the period from years to months.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &= 12\times10
\\[5pt]
&= 120
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the period is 120.

Let's now calculate the amount remaining from his pre-retirement savings after purchasing the cabin.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Amount Remaining} &= \$469,707.66-\$345,000
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$124,707.66}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the amount of savings from pre-retirement is $124,707.66.

Now, we will constitute the excess amount remaining from Baggin's pre-retirement savings to the total amount he needs 30 years from now for his retirement. Since the remaining amount is ten years from now and Baggin's retirement is 30 years from this point, we will calculate the future value of the remaining amount by discounting it 20 years.

In determining the future value of the remaining amount of Baggin's savings, we will consider the following details:

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| Present value | $124,707.66 |
| Rate | 9.57%  |
| Period              | 20 (years) |


We will consider the amount remaining as the present value.

The future value can be calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV} &=PV\times\left(1 + r\right)^{t}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which means the future value\
$PV$, which refers to the present value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate

Convert the period from years to months.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &= 12\times20
\\[5pt]
&= 240
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the period is 240.

Now, considering the future value of Baggin's savings from the previous step,  subtract the savings amount to the total amount required after retirement. We will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{NPT Amount Required} &= \text{PT Total Amount Required}-\text{Future Value of Savings}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:
- NPT refers to net post-retirement.
- PT means Post-Retirement

Let's now determine the remaining amount required after retirement.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{NPT Amount Required} &= \$2,894,910.01 
-\$839,142.48
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$2,055,767.54}
\end{aligned}$$

Based on our calculation, the remaining amount required after Baggin's retirement to meet his objectives is $2,055,767.54.
Finally, now that we have Baggin's net amount required after retirement, we will calculate the monthly savings after ten years Baggin should save to cover the remaining amount after 30 years.

In calculating the monthly savings, we will use the PMT spreadsheet function. 

The PMT function is a financial function that calculates the monthly payment of an investment or a loan considering the periodic payment and the interest.

We can use the PMT function in a spreadsheet using the formula as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

We will consider the following given in calculating the monthly savings:

| **Particulars**         |     |
|---------------------|-----|
| Future value | $ 2,055,767.54  |
| Rate | 0.798%  |
| Period              | 240 (monthly) |

Note that the rate is divided by twelve since we compute a monthly value.

Let's now calculate the amount of monthly savings Baggin should save.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/ba93fb90-bfd8-4bba-8bac-98c4779b8cbf-1642614306276521.png)

**As can be seen in our calculation, to meet Baggin's objective, he will have to save $2,861.77 monthly after ten years to cover the remaining amount required for his retirement.**

To conclude, Baggin should save a monthly of $2,861.77 from the eleventh year to the thirtieth year to meet all his objectives. We determined the amount to save by considering the present value of his objectives and subtracting the future value of his ten-year savings.
